          next
         Prime Minister, Giorgia Meloni in the courtyard of Palazzo Chigi. Rome (Italy), July 25, 2024. (Massimo Di Vita/Archivio Massimo Di Vita/Mondadori Portfolio via Getty Images)  Image 2 of 2 
          prev
          Climate activist Greta Thunberg with other activists talks with journalists in Catania, Italy on Sunday ahead of her first flotilla to Gaza.  (AP)

         Prime Minister, Giorgia Meloni in the courtyard of Palazzo Chigi. Rome (Italy), July 25, 2024. (Massimo Di Vita/Archivio Massimo Di Vita/Mondadori Portfolio via Getty Images)
Prime Minister, Giorgia Meloni in the courtyard of Palazzo Chigi. Rome (Italy), July 25, 2024. (Massimo Di Vita/Archivio Massimo Di Vita/Mondadori Portfolio via Getty Images)

Image 2 of 2 
          prev

Climate activist Greta Thunberg with other activists talks with journalists in Catania, Italy on Sunday ahead of her first flotilla to Gaza.  (AP)
TRUMP SAYS ‘REAL CHANCE FOR GREATNESS’ AS NETANYAHU WHITE HOUSE MEETING LOOMS FOR GAZA TALKS

The flotilla has drawn international attention not only because of Thunberg’s participation but also because of its European and regional connections. The fleet departed from Barcelona, with activists supported by groups in Spain, which Jerusalem claims is tied to Hamas operative Saif Abu Kashk, who allegedly runs a front company that Israeli intelligence claims controls many of the ships.

At the same time, Turkey says it has been monitoring the flotilla with drones, with Ankara saying it may assist further "on humanitarian grounds." Turkey has been accused of sheltering Hamas members in the country.
President Trump hosted Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu at the White House as the pair looks to reach a peace deal in the Gaza war. ( Win McNamee/Getty Images)

For Israel, observers say the challenge is to prevent activists from reaching Gaza while avoiding an international incident that could play into Hamas’s hands. As Trump works to lock in a deal, the looming confrontation at sea risks shifting headlines away from diplomacy and back toward conflict.
CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP

On Tuesday, Israel released documents tying the flotilla’s organizers to Hamas through the Palestinian Conference for Palestinians Abroad (PCPA). The group, established in Turkey in 2017, has been designated a terrorist organization by Israel and accused of serving as Hamas’s overseas arm.

Efrat Lachter is an investigative reporter and war correspondent. Her work has taken her to 40 countries, including Ukraine, Russia, Iraq, Syria, Sudan and Afghanistan. She is a recipient of the 2024 Knight-Wallace Fellowship for Journalism. Lachter can be followed on X @efratlachter.

title: The 15 most banned books in U.S. schools
summary: "A Clockwork Orange," "Last Night at the Telegraph Club" and "Wicked" are among the most banned books of the 2024-2025 school year, according to PEN America.
story: The most commonly banned books in U.S. schools include LGBTQ titles, international bestsellers, teen romantasy novels and a 1962 classic, according to a new report that compares modern-day censorship to Cold War-era McCarthyism.

More than 6,800 book bans were enacted during the 2024-25 school year in 87 public school districts across 23 states, according to a report released Wednesday by PEN America, a nonprofit that advocates for free expression. The report was released ahead of Banned Books Week, which starts Sunday.

“Censorship pressures have expanded and escalated,” Kasey Meehan, director of PEN America’s Freedom to Read program, said in a news release. “A disturbing ‘everyday banning’ and normalization of censorship has worsened and spread over the last four years.”

The organization’s annual “Banned in the USA” report says the current environment of “unfettered book banning is reminiscent of the Red Scare of the 1950s.” It defines a school book ban as “any action taken against a book based on its content and as a result of parent or community challenges, administrative decisions, or in response to direct or threatened action by governmental officials” that leads to the book being removed or restricted.

The latest report found that 3,752 unique titles were affected by bans in the school year that ended in June. The most banned titles included “A Clockwork Orange” and “Wicked,” while the most banned authors included Stephen King, Sarah J. Maas and Jodi Picoult. More than 80% of all bans originated in just three states: Florida, Texas and Tennessee.

This past school year saw fewer total bans than in 2023-24, at more than 10,000, though the number is far above where it was in 2021-22 (more than 2,500 bans), when PEN America first started to compile an annual report. Since July 2021, PEN America has tracked 22,810 book bans across 45 states.
One reason the total number of book bans may have dipped this year is that some titles are being pre-emptively taken off the shelves.

“This functions as a form of ‘obeying in advance’ to anticipated restrictions from the state or administrative authorities, rooted in fear or simply a desire to avoid topics that might be deemed controversial,” the report states.

Another potential reason, as author Malinda Lo pointed out, is that previously banned titles have not returned to shelves. Lo, whose book “Last Night at the Telegraph Club” was No. 4 on PEN America’s new list, said on Instagram that her 2021 novel made the cut “partly because all of the usual titles like ‘Gender Queer’ have already been banned and removed.”
“Once a book is banned, it’s gone,” she wrote on Wednesday. “This is why we have to keep fighting these attacks on our first amendment rights.”
“Gender Queer,” a graphic memoir that debuted in 2019, was No. 1 on PEN America’s Most Banned Books List in 2022, though it didn’t even make the top 15 on this year’s list.

Books with LGBTQ themes and characters — like “Gender Queer” and “Last Night at the Telegraph Club” — are consistently among the most banned books highlighted in the annual reports of PEN America and the American Library Association, and this year is no different.
Here are the 15 most banned books this past school year as tracked by PEN America, ranked in order of those banned by the most public school districts across the country:
‘A Clockwork Orange’ by Anthony Burgess

Burgess’ dystopian satire about a sociopathic, Beethoven-obsessed teen gang leader was banned in 23 districts in the 2024-25 school year. The 1962 novel was adapted into an Oscar-nominated film by Stanley Kubrick in 1971 and was named one of Time’s 100 best English-language novels and one of Modern Library’s 100 Best Novels.
‘Breathless’ by Jennifer Niven

Niven’s 2020 novel is a coming-of-age love story that was banned in 20 school districts. On her website, the bestselling author describes “Breathless” as “the book I needed when I was sixteen, seventeen, eighteen. A frank take on sex and love, parental divorce, finding yourself, and the importance of writing your story. Of writing your life.”
‘Sold’ by Patricia McCormick

McCormick’s young-adult novel, about a girl from Nepal who is sold into sexual slavery in India, was banned in 20 school districts in the last school year. This 2006 title was a National Book Award finalist and was on the Publisher’s Weekly Best Books of the Year list and the ALA’s Top Ten Books for Young Adults list.
‘Last Night at the Telegraph Club’ by Malinda Lo

Lo’s young-adult historical novel about love and duty in 1950s San Francisco was banned in 19 school districts in the 2024-25 school year. The critically acclaimed 2021 novel won a long list of awards, including a National Book Award, Stonewall Book Award and Asian/Pacific American Award for Literature.
‘A Court of Mist and Fury’ by Sarah J. Maas

This bestselling adult romantasy novel, which was banned in 18 districts in the 2024-25 school year, is the second book in Maas’ wildly popular “A Court of Thorns and Roses” series. Maas, the only author with more than one title on this top 15 list, also has the distinction of being one of the most banned authors this year, with 162 total bans, behind only Stephen King and “Crank” author Ellen Hopkins.
‘Crank’ by Ellen Hopkins

Hopkins’ 2004 young-adult novel was banned in 17 school districts. On her website, the author revealed this bestseller is loosely based on her “older daughter’s story of addiction to crystal meth.” She said “Crank” began as “a personal exploration of the ‘why’s’ behind my daughter’s decisions, and what part I might have played in them.”
‘Forever…’ by Judy Blume

Blume’s award-winning 1975 young-adult novel, which was banned in 17 districts in the last school year, has been a target of censorship for 50 years, according to PEN America. Blume said she wrote the book — which was named one of NPR’s 100 Best-Ever Teen Novels and Time’s 100 Best YA Books of All Time — because her daughter “asked for a story about two nice kids who have sex without either of them having to die.”
‘The Perks of Being a Wallflower’ by Stephen Chbosky

Chbosky’s 1999 coming-of-age novel about an observant “wallflower” navigating the “strange world between adolescence and adulthood” was banned in 17 school districts in the 2024-25 school year. The No. 1 New York Times bestseller — which deals with topics including first dates, family drama, sex, drugs and suicide — was adapted into a 2012 film starring Logan Lerman, Emma Watson and Ezra Miller.
‘Wicked’ by Gregory Maguire

This No. 1 New York Times bestseller, which debuted in 1995 and is a reimagined prequel to “The Wonderful Wizard of Oz,” was banned in 17 school districts. The story of “Wicked,” however, is perhaps best known due to its adaptation into a Tony-winning Broadway musical and an Oscar-winning musical film starring Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande.
‘All Boys Aren’t Blue’ by George M. Johnson

Johnson’s 2020 memoir-manifesto about coming of age as a queer Black man was banned in 16 districts in the last school year, and it also topped the ALA’s list of 10 most challenged library books of 2024. In an interview with NBC News last year, Johnson said the real book censorship danger lies in the “soft-banning”: “We can track the books that are being banned, but we can’t track books that are not being ordered.”
‘A Court of Thorns and Roses’ by Sarah J. Maas

The first book in Maas’ internationally bestselling five-book romantasy series was, like the remaining books on this list, banned in 16 school districts. The central character in 2015’s “A Court of Thorns and Roses” is 19-year-old Feyre, a moral huntress who is dragged to a magical land and falls for her immortal captor.
‘Damsel’ by Elana K. Arnold

This dark and twisted fairy tale, a 2019 Michael L. Printz Award Honor Book, is, on the surface, about a damsel who is rescued from a dragon by a handsome prince. Prior to “Damsel,” Arnold’s book “What Girls Are Made Of” was a finalist for the 2017 National Book Award in Young People’s Literature.
‘The DUFF’ by Kody Keplinger

In Keplinger’s 2010 young-adult novel, 17-year-old Bianca discovers her high school’s “slimy school hottie” has given her an offensive nickname — DUFF, or Designated Ugly Fat Friend — but she still ends up in a “closeted enemies-with-benefits relationship” with him. Keplinger was only 17 herself when she wrote this bestselling book, which was adapted into a 2015 film.
‘Nineteen Minutes’ by Jodi Picoult

This No. 1 New York Times bestseller is about the aftermath of a school shooting in a small New Hampshire town. Published in 2007, this is one of 29 novels written by Picoult, whose other works include “My Sister’s Keeper,” “Small Great Things” and “The Pact.”
‘Storm and Fury’ by Jennifer L. Armentrout

Armentrout’s 2019 romantasy novel is the first book in her three-book “Harbinger” series. “Storm and Fury” is centered on 18-year-old Trinity Marrow, who “may be going blind” but “can see and communicate with ghosts and spirits,” according to Armentrout’s website.

title: U.K.'s public health service is in crisis, threatening a British institution
summary: “Nye,” an unlikely hit about the creator, and origin story, of Britain’s taxpayer-funded National Health Service, came at an inflection point for the NHS.
story: LONDON — Despite being headlined by a genuine star and staged at one of London’s premier theaters, a play about the foundation of a sprawling and troubled public service seemed unlikely to provoke night after night of standing ovations.
But that’s what happened with “Nye,” an unlikely hit about the creator, and origin story, of Britain’s taxpayer-funded National Health Service.

The play, written by Tim Price and directed by Rufus Norris, came at an inflection point for the NHS, as it’s known. Almost 80 years after it was founded, the medical service once touted as the envy of the world is “broken” and suffering the “biggest crisis in its history,” the government says. The crisis at this national bedrock is part of a bigger malaise at the heart of British culture: rising prices, stagnant wages and crumbling public services.

“I’m terrified, not just for the NHS, but for the whole of our society,” Michael Sheen, who starred as Aneurin “Nye” Bevan, the founder of the NHS, told NBC News in an interview. “Once it’s torn down, then I guess people will think about what they’ve lost.”

Sheen, 56, better known to international audiences as Tony Blair in “The Queen,” David Frost in “Frost/Nixon” and the angel Aziraphale in the Amazon Prime series “Good Omens,” has spent much of the last two years honing his portrayal of Bevan, the socialist politician who dragged himself out of Wales’ coal mines to will the NHS into existence.

Though second nature to Brits, the ideal of the NHS is unfamiliar to many Americans: British people have universally free health care at the point of access — from ambulances attending car accidents to insulin for diabetes to cancer care to childbirth. Though some people do have private insurance, the idea of having to choose between illness and financial ruin is shocking in the U.K.

Now, the Labour Party, which created the then-radical NHS in 1948, is battling its own economic constraints and record-setting unpopularity. It has a colossal task if it is to fix the crumbling hospitals replete with overworked doctors and bed-lined corridors.

Prime Minister Keir Starmer must turn around a behemoth whose budget of 200 billion English pounds ($269 billion) represents some 40% of all government spending, and whose 1.4 million employees are the world’s seventh-largest workforce. In the United States, only the Department of Defense, Walmart and Amazon employ more people.

Through all this, the core NHS ideal endures. Everyone in the U.K. has a story of a relative, or themselves, receiving the type of world-class care that puts a terrifying financial strain on millions of Americans. (In the past six years, this reporter’s mother has had a single mastectomy and reconstruction, as well as three titanium plates in a shattered ankle, without having to pay a pound for the care.)

But just as common are the tales of maddening, hourslong waits in overstretched emergency rooms, or weeklong delays just to see a community general practitioner. Many critics blame the sprawling crisis on years of underfunding by the now-ousted Conservative government of 2010-24, whose response to the 2008 financial crisis was to make drastic cuts to public services.

It’s perhaps unsurprising that a largely liberal London-theatergoing audience responded with applause and tears at the hagiography of Bevan at the National Theater. Though relatively unknown in wider society, admirers see Bevan as a founding father of modern Britain; his ideal of the NHS today is not just popular, it defines the country itself.

“It’s far from perfect,” said Alison Ferris, 40, a nurse at a hospital in Canterbury, in southeast England. “But I do the best that I can for anyone that comes in front of me. I treat every patient like I would treat my loved ones.”

Though the concept remains revered, public satisfaction in the NHS in practice cratered to 52% in 2023 from a high of 70% in 2010, according to the King’s Fund, a top think tank tracking British health care.

“We have to fight for the NHS, the same as the NHS was fought for when it was created,” said Ferris’ mother, Caroline Heggie, 70, a hospital union representative, who like her daughter had come to see the last night of “Nye” at the National Theater last month. “We can’t go the way of privatization, we can’t go the way of America. That’s what we’re up against.”
Like Bevan, Sheen is a Welsh firebrand unafraid to wear his leftist politics. But he also lived for 14 years in Los Angeles, so knows too well what life is like without socialized health care.

“The idea of this health care system that we have here, just seemed so alien to them over there,” Sheen, who now lives back in his Welsh hometown of Port Talbot, says of his former American hosts. He says that “seeing people go into hospitals with serious injuries or illnesses, and being asked to produce their checkbook before they can be treated” would shock most Britons.

The crisis at the NHS coincides with an uptick in hostility toward immigrants — even though they are often people’s doctors, nurses and hospital cleaners. Almost 20% of NHS staff have a non-British nationality, with Indians, Filipinos, Nigerians, Irish and Poles making up most of their number.

Nigel Farage, the leader of the hard-right Reform U.K. party and an ally and friend of President Donald Trump, is leading some polls to become Britain’s next prime minister. He has become the first prospective leader to question the funding model of using taxes to fund the NHS — historically taboo.

“It doesn’t work — it’s not working,” Farage told NBC News’ British partner Sky News in May. “We’re getting worse bang for the buck than any other country, particularly out of those European neighbors.”

Opposing Farage’s proposal, however, leaves open the specter of privatization, which many say has been creeping up even before the Health and Social Care Act 2012 opened up the NHS to bids from private contractors.
Farage isn’t the only person dissatisfied. Indeed, the NHS has slipped from being a world leader on many metrics.

“Corridor care” is now a year-round crisis, and the number of people waiting 12 hours or more to be admitted into an emergency room rose from 47 in summer 2015 to 74,150 this summer. Targets have lagged for years in everything from ambulance attendance times to cancer diagnoses. Meanwhile, a 7 million-strong waiting list means many people feel abandoned for months, in pain, before getting hip or knee replacement and other types of surgery.

There is ample evidence to suggest that economic austerity policies imposed during 14 years of Conservative Party rule are at least partly to blame, according to Max Warner, a senior research economist at the Institute for Fiscal Studies, a London research group.

“It is true that a lot of NHS performance measures over the 2010s were broadly getting worse, having started off relatively well,” he said. “Although it’s worth saying that productivity did grow, so it’s a nuanced picture and causality is difficult.”

The Conservatives argued that they kept NHS spending up, protecting it from the brutal cuts that crushed almost every other government department at the time. But this 2% yearly growth still fell well short of the 3.8% yearly average since the 1980s, and, according to critics, was insufficient to cope with an aging population and the rising prices of cutting-edge drugs.

Far from the envy of the world, Britain has been scrimping by spending 37 billion pounds ($53 billion) on the health services each year, well below Germany, France and Australia, a landmark review found last year.

The current Labour government has outlined plans to raise spending to around 3% — an improvement but still short of what many advocates had hoped. At his annual Labour Party conference this week, Starmer announced that a digital overhaul named NHS Online would launch in 2027, describing it as “a new chapter in the story of our NHS.”
Ultimately, whatever the model, cash is key, according to Roy Lilley, who ran an NHS hospital in the 1990s as chairman of Homewood NHS Trust in Surrey, west of London.

“It doesn’t matter how you pay for your health care,” said Lilley, today a consultant whose newsletter hits 300,000 inboxes. “Whether you take it out of your pocket marked ‘insurance,’ or you take it out of your pocket marked ‘taxes,’ it’s still your trousers.”
He remains optimistic, however, pointing to some waiting metrics improving and a general recovery from the hammerblow of the pandemic, which drained resources and mentally scarred doctors.
Still, Sheen — never shy to mix acting with activism — believes it’s no coincidence that the NHS is in crisis just when its origin story begins to vanish from living memory.

“The crisis that we seem to be experiencing makes it all the more important to go back to the beginning and to look at what was behind the founding of the NHS, and what the principles were,” he said. “It becomes incredibly important to tell the story of it and to remind people of what it was actually like, so that we don’t forget.”

title: So far, the Philadelphia Eagles' toughest opponent could be themselves
summary: A month into the NFL season, one team — Team A, let’s call it — has yet to gain more yards than any of its opponents
story: A month into the NFL season, one team — Team A, let’s call it — has yet to gain more yards than any of its opponents.

Team A’s passing offense is ghastly. Last week, its rarely thrown-to star receiver posted a cryptic message on Twitter after the team failed to complete a single pass after halftime. Another MVP-level offensive weapon isn’t producing as expected, either. And statistically speaking, its defense ranks around average.
Those might sound like the hallmarks of a team going nowhere. But Team A isn’t the 0-4 Jets, Titans or Saints, or the stunningly 1-3 Ravens, either.
It’s the Philadelphia Eagles, who have followed a Super Bowl title last season with a 4-0 start to the new season. They join Buffalo as the lone undefeated teams entering Week 5.
These are the same Eagles who have won 20 of their last 21 games and whose 12-game home winning streak is the second longest in franchise history, since nearly World War II.
By their record, the Eagles are unblemished. Yet that doesn’t mean it has come without drama.
Much of it has been sparked by whether they have a dynamic enough offense to repeat as champions.

When quarterback Jalen Hurts went 0-for-8 after halftime last week against previously unbeaten Tampa Bay, star receiver A.J. Brown posted on X a Scripture passage: “If you’re not welcomed, not listened to, quietly withdraw. Don’t make a scene. Shrug your shoulders and be on your way.”
Did Brown intimate he wanted to be on his way out of town, after averaging just 3.5 catches per game?
Nick Sirianni, the team’s head coach, said he didn’t doubt Brown’s willingness to be an Eagle and a “good teammate.”
“He wants to contribute into these wins, and he’s had a couple games where he hasn’t been able to, for different reasons of why we haven’t in these games,” Sirianni said.
Brown later deleted the post and said it was not directed toward anyone specific.
“We have a lot of talent on offense, and, to be honest, defense and special teams have been low-key carrying us,” Brown said Wednesday, according to The Philadelphia Inquirer.

“We need to clean up what we need to clean up and get on the same page and play to the ability that we say we can, and be who we are called to be. It’s a standard that we preach. So it’s easy to have that frustration. I think it’s fair to have that frustration. But I just can’t let that boil over.”

Yet the fact remains that no offense has gained fewer first downs via passes than the Eagles, who have also completed the league’s third-fewest passes. They are averaging 6.0 yards per pass attempt, which is nearly two yards behind last season’s average. A passing game that brought back most of the players who helped produce 12 explosive plays of 40-plus yards last season, tied for second most, has generated just one in four games. The offense is run by a first-year coordinator, after his predecessor, Kellen Moore, parlayed last season’s Super Bowl run into a head coaching job in New Orleans. But Brown’s post also rekindled speculation about the strength of the working relationship between Brown and quarterback Jalen Hurts — a topic of debate for two years in Philadelphia.
“It’s good,” Hurts told reporters this week.
“I’m not gonna analyze or speculate” about Brown’s post, Hurts said. “He’s always willing to contribute, and that remains.”

The kinks in the passing offense wouldn’t be as worrisome if the Eagles’ vaunted running game weren’t also enduring its own. The combination has led to Jekyll-and-Hyde performances where the offense has sometimes looked explosive, and sometimes produced zilch.
“We got to be more consistent,” Sirianni said this week.

While turning the “Tush Push” quarterback sneak into a nearly unstoppable (and nearly banned) weapon in short-yardage situations, and blocking for running back Saquon Barkley as he became only the ninth 2,000-yard rusher in NFL history last season, the Eagles’ offensive line earned a reputation as the NFL’s very best. This season, however, three players are coming off either offseason surgery or playing through injury, while a fourth is in his first season as starter.

Last season, that line created so much room for Barkley to run that he gained an average of 3.8 yards before being hit, the highest of any running back, according to Pro Football Reference. This season, that average has dropped to 1.7 yards before contact, and Barkley has had defenders in his face much more quickly.

Through four games, Barkley has gained half as many yards per carry than at the same point last season. And Barkley, last season’s offensive player of the year, has yet to gain more than 100 yards from scrimmage in a single game.
“When the running game is going bad, I’ve got to own it,” Barkley said after last week’s win in Tampa. “The beauty of it is we’re not running the ball too great and we’re 4-0.”
What else we’re watching for in Week 5:

Minnesota (2-2) vs. Cleveland (1-3): The league’s third international game this season, in London, is the backdrop for Browns quarterback Dillon Gabriel’s first career start after replacing Joe Flacco. The last Browns quarterback to win in his first start was Eric Zeier in 1995.
Denver (2-2) at Philadelphia (4-0): The Broncos have lost five consecutive road games dating to last season but lead the league with 15 sacks.

Las Vegas (1-3) at Indianapolis (3-1): The Colts could become the first team since 1945 to go three consecutive home games without a punt. The Raiders, meanwhile, have lost seven straight games against winning teams.

Houston (1-3) at Baltimore (1-3): Division winners from last season who harbored similar playoff aspirations this year find themselves in a world of trouble. The Texans are coming off only their third shutout in franchise history. Baltimore’s Derrick Henry is one rushing touchdown from tying Walter Payton (110) for the fifth most in NFL history.

Giants (1-3) at New Orleans (0-4): After a win in his first career start, Giants quarterback Jaxson Dart will try to end his team’s seven-game losing streak on the road. His Saints counterpart, Spencer Rattler, is 0-10 for his career.

Dallas (1-2-1) at Jets (0-4): The good: The Cowboys lead the NFL with 404.3 yards per game. The bad: Their defense has allowed even more, ranking dead last. The Jets have yet to force a turnover — the only team yet to do so.

Miami (1-3) at Carolina (1-3): The Panthers recommitted to Bryce Young as the starter. All three of their losses have been on the road. Miami is 21-8 against teams with losing records under coach Mike McDaniel.

Tampa Bay (3-1) at Seattle (3-1): Can Seattle end its struggles at home? Since 2022, the Buccaneers have lost six straight games when playing without receiver Mike Evans, who will miss this game with a hamstring injury.
Tennessee (0-4) at Arizona (2-2): The Titans are trying to avoid their first 0-5 start since 2009, while the Cardinals have lost two straight.

Washington (2-2) at Chargers (3-1): Chargers running back Omarion Hampton leads all rookies with 380 yards from scrimmage this season; that includes 110 through the air. The Commanders are 0-2 on the road.

Detroit (3-1) at Cincinnati (2-2): While it’s obvious the Bengals would struggle without quarterback Joe Burrow, they’ve also become the first team since the 2009 Raiders to fail to gain more than 200 yards in three of their first four games.
New England (2-2) at Buffalo (4-0): Josh Allen has 34 touchdowns and two turnovers in his last 13 games. If the Bills win, they’ll be 5-0 for the first time since 1991.

Kansas City (2-2) at Jacksonville (3-1) on Monday: Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes threw for more touchdowns (four) last week than he had in his first three games combined. The Jaguars have forced a league-best 13 turnovers.

title: 43+ actually good early October Prime Day deals
summary: You don’t have to wait until October 7 to save — here are the top early Prime Day discounts live today.
story: Amazon’s October Prime Day, Prime Big Deal Days, is just days away — this year it runs from Oct. 7 to 8, and, like years’ past, it’s exclusive to Prime members. But that doesn’t mean you should wait to shop. The retailer is dropping new early deals daily from some of our favorite brands like Apple, Neutrogena and Shark. And if you check out soon, you’ll get the exact size, style or model you’re looking for, which is especially important if you’re starting to buy gifts for loved ones.

I frequently cover shopping events like Prime Day, Black Friday and Cyber Monday as a writer for NBC Select, so I know how to find deals that are actually worth buying. I combed through thousands of discounts to find the best early October Prime Day deals — each one I recommend below is highly rated and 20% off or more, as well as at its lowest price in at least three months or lowest price ever. I’ll frequently update this list leading up to Prime Big Deal Days.

CeraVe Skin Renewing Vitamin C Eye Cream

CeraVe’s fragrance-free eye cream is made with vitamin C to brighten dark under eyes and caffeine to reduce puffiness, plus hyaluronic acid and ceramides to moisturize skin, according to the brand. It has a lightweight, non-sticky, non-greasy feel that quickly absorbs into skin, and is safe for those who wear contacts, according to Cerave. The brand recommends using it twice daily.
Ecolution Micro-Pop Microwave Popcorn Popper

Ecolution’s Micro-Pop is one of my favorite kitchen gadgets because it helps me make fresh, warm popcorn in minutes (trust me, it’s way better than the store-bought stuff). You add kernels to the built-in measuring cup on the lid, pour them into the bowl and place it in the microwave for about three minutes. You can also put butter on top of the lid, which has holes in it;  as the butter melts in the microwave, it drips onto the popcorn. The 3-quart, dishwasher-safe popper has a wide opening, so once it cools down, it doubles as a serving bowl.
Amazon Fire TV Stick HD

Stream your favorite shows, movies, music and more from any TV when you plug this Fire Stick into an HDMI port. It comes with an Alexa Voice Remote, letting you adjust settings via voice commands, and it displays pictures in vibrant HD. You can also use the Fire Stick to control compatible smart home devices like thermostats, cameras and lights.
Amazon Smart Plug

Plug devices like fans, air purifiers and small kitchen appliances into this smart plug to control them via the Amazon Alexa app or voice commands.  The app also lets you set up schedules, timers and routines for your devices.  The plug is compact, so it won’t block your second outlet.
Oral-B iO Deep Clean Rechargeable Electric Powered Toothbrush

Oral-B’s electric toothbrush has all the features dentists told me to look for while shopping: a pressure sensor, a built-in timer, multiple cleaning settings and a brush head change alert. The rechargeable toothbrush comes with two replacement brush heads and a travel case.
Shark Lift-Away Upright Vacuum (ZD201)

This corded upright vacuum, which is suitable for all floor types, has a detachable pod you can tote around your home to clean above doorframes, under furniture,on top of upholstery and on stairs. Its HEPA filter traps dust and other allergens while it suctions up debris, and its LED headlights illuminate dirt so you don’t miss spots. The vacuum comes with crevice and upholstery tools.
Neutrogena Hydro Boost Body Lotion

Neutrogena's lightweight, fragrance-free body lotion hydrates skin using ingredients like hyaluronic acid, and it absorbs quickly without leaving behind a greasy or oily residue. It's also safe for sensitive-skin, according to the brand.
Batiste Original Dry Shampoo (3 pack)

Don't worry about running out of dry shampoo when you buy this pack of three bottles — you can use one now and save the others for later, or keep one at home and put the others in your toiletry bag. Batiste's Original formula is made with keratin, and it absorbs oil and grease at your roots to leave your hair looking and feeling clean between washes. It also adds volume. The dry shampoo is scented with orange, lily and rose.
Shark Wandvac WV200 Series Handheld Vacuum

Keep this handheld vacuum on hand at home for small messes, or use it to clean your car. It's lightweight at only 1.4 pounds, and it comes with a charging dock, duster crevice tool and multi-surface pet hair tool. You empty the Wandvac by holding it over a trash can and pressing a button, which pops the dustbin open to discards debris.
Magna-Tiles Dino World 40-Piece Magnetic Construction Set

"Magna-Tiles are without a doubt the number one toy students fought over at school when I was a pre-school teacher," says NBC Select editorial projects manager Rebecca Rodriguez. This set comes with 40 multi-colored pieces, including four dinosaur figurines. The pieces are compatible with Magna-Tiles from other sets, too.
Ring Battery Doorbell Plus

See, hear and speak to visitors with this video doorbell. It pairs with Ring’s app, which shows you HD livestream footage (including in color night vision) and sends you alerts when the device detects people, packages or motion. The doorbell is powered by a removable, rechargeable battery, so there’s no electrical work required for setup, and it comes with mounting tools, too.
Amazon Echo Pop

This Bluetooth speaker may be small, but it’s loud enough to fill a room with sound whether you’re listening to music, a podcast or an audiobook. It has Amazon Alexa built-in, so you can use voice commands to ask questions, set timers and reminders, control compatible smart home devices and more. I keep my Echo Pop in my bedroom and ask Alexa about the weather while I’m getting dressed every day. The device has volume control buttons, as well as a button to turn the microphone off.
Belif Vitamin E Jelly Overnight Mask

Dry skin season is upon us now that the temperatures are dropping, so adding more hydrating products to your routine might be beneficial. This lightweight, no-rinse mask creates a barrier over your skin to lock in moisture overnight. It’s made with ingredients like hyaluronic acid and niacinamide, which leave your skin feeling smoother and looking more plump after use, according to the brand.
Kindle Paperwhite Signature Edition Essentials Bundle

You get a Kindle Paperwhite, fabric cover and wireless charging dock with this bundle, covering all your essentials if you’re getting your first e-reader or upgrading. The Paperwhite has a 7-inch glare-free screen and a 12-week battery life, according to the brand, plus its front light automatically adjusts to whatever environment you’re in. It’s also water-resistant, so you can read at the beach, pool or in the bath. The cover that’s included with this bundle attaches to your e-reader, waking it up or putting it to sleep as you open and close it like a book.
Amazon Blink Mini 2

The Blink Mini 2 is one of my favorite security cameras because it’s so small — it blends into my space instead of being an eyesore. You can use it indoors and outdoors, and it connects to the Blink app, where you can livestream HD footage, hear audio and speak to people and pets. The camera also has a built-in spotlight, and you can use it as a plug-in chime with Blink Video Doorbells (which are also currently on sale). The app sends you motion detection alerts, too.
Blueair 311i Max Air Purifier

Air purifiers like this one can remove tiny airborne particles from your home, like allergens, dust, smoke, bacteria and pet hair. The Blueair 311i connects to WiFi and pairs with the brand’s app, letting you adjust its mode (auto or night), fan speed, brightness and child lock setting, as well as track filter usage, air quality and more. The appliance is best for medium rooms and it responds to voice commands, too.

Best early October Prime Day promos
Before Prime Big Deal Days, Amazon is offering a handful of special promos. Here are a few notable ones to know about.

How I found the best early October Prime Day deals

Why trust NBC Select?

title: Meghan Markle Makes Her Paris Fashion Week Debut in All White. See the Pics
summary: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, stepped out at Paris Fashion Week over the weekend, donning timeless black-and-white looks for a night out.
story: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, stepped out at Paris Fashion Week over the weekend, donning timeless black-and-white looks for a night out.

The former Meghan Markle made her Paris Fashion Week debut Saturday, Oct. 4 dressed in an all-white pant suit with a wrap-around matching shawl. She accompanied the monochrome fabric with a black pointed-toe heel and slicked-back bun.
Meghan attended the Balenciaga show featuring the fashion house's spring and summer 2026 womenswear line.

On Instagram, Meghan shared a video recapping her Parisian excursion, including shots of notable French monuments, such as the Eiffel Tower and the Arc de Triomphe, her getting glammed up for the fashion show and a screenshot of a 100-day streak on language-learning app Duolingo.
The video also showed Meghan walking out in her white ensemble to photographers, and hugging Balenciaga creative director Pierpaolo Piccioli.
“About last night,” she captioned the video, thanking Piccioli and Balenciaga, adding a French flag and red heart emoji. “I’ve missed you — thanks for the love.”
On her Instagram story, Meghan shared a clip of herself with her feet up during a car ride, showing off her legs and black heels.
Meghan then appeared to have an outfit change, as she was photographed leaving the Balenciaga dinner after the fashion show Saturday night.

Pictured later in the evening, she wore an ankle-length column dress with a partially open back and draping fabric sweeping along her neckline. She paired the look with another pair of black heels and once again sported a slicked-back bun.
Paris Fashion Week 2025 began Monday, Sept. 29 and is set to run through Tuesday, Oct. 7.

title: All About the True Story That Inspired Dwayne Johnson's 'The Smashing Machine'
summary: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson takes on one of his most personal and fitting roles in “The Smashing Machine,” which is based on Mark Kerr's real life. What to know.
story: Warning: Spoilers ahead for “The Smashing Machine”
Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson takes on one of his most personal and fitting roles in “The Smashing Machine.”

The film, directed by Benny Safdie, follows pioneering mixed martial arts and UFC fighter Mark Kerr over a four-year period in his life as he ascended to fame while MMA was relatively on the up and up. The biopic also shines a light on Kerr amid his own struggles with addiction and a toxic relationship.

“The Smashing Machine” is based on a 2002 HBO documentary of the same name. The film, now in theaters, premiered at the Venice Film Festival on Sept. 1, 2025, with people applauding Johnson’s role and physical transformation to become Kerr. Emily Blunt stars as Kerr’s first wife, Dawn Staples.

“Mark was the greatest fighter in the world at one point, but this film is not even really about fighting — it’s a love story,” Johnson said at the festival. “It’s a love story about Mark and Dawn in this relationship, and it’s a love story about Mark and the love that he had for the thing that he did — his struggle with trying to deliver (in the ring), his challenges and his overcoming.”
He adds, “As you know, Mark OD’d twice, and he’s lucky to be alive — and that’s part of why this story is so special.”
Read on to learn more about the true story that inspired “The Smashing Machine.”
The True Story Behind 'The Smashing Machine'
“The Smashing Machine” takes place from 1997 to 2000, chronicling Mark Kerr’s biggest fights while in the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) and in international tournaments in Brazil and Japan.

One of Kerr's first fights was in 1997 in Brazil, which was re-created for the film. In the movie, Johnson’s Kerr is seen coming out of a striking pyramid with smoke, as it happened in real life. The real-life Kerr got a kick out of that re-creation.

“I was in Vancouver for the set and I was laughing with Benny about it going, ‘Alright, who came up with the pyramid?’” Kerr recalled during a Sept. 25 appearance on the “Joe Rogan Experience” podcast. “The door opening with the fog machines?’...But they reproduced it to a T.”

The soft-spoken athlete received his nickname, The Smashing Machine, for his fierce abilities inside the ring and following his success at the World Vale Tudo Championship 3 in Brazil, according to the UFC.
Kerr would go on to make his UFC debut during the tournament of UFC 14: Showdown, which took place on July 27, 1997, in Birmingham, Alabama.
After defeating both of his opponents, Moti Horenstein and Dan Bobish, he won the heavyweight tournament, UFC notes.
In October of that same year, Kerr won his second consecutive UFC heavyweight tournament title during the Collision Course event that took place Oct. 17, 1997.

As the film depicts, following his UFC wins, Kerr headed to Japan to compete in the MMA promotion Pride Fighting Championships. According to the UFC, Kerr won six of his first eight fights in Pride as a heavyweight.
He did have his losses, which are seen in the movie, that also triggered his health struggles. One fight in particular, against Igor Vovchanchyn, ended in a no-contest, which set him over the edge.
"That was the straw that literally set me over the top," Kerr told Johnson in a joint interview for Sports Illustrated.
Amid his success in the ring, his life behind closed doors proved to be quite the opposite.
His Struggles With Addiction and Overdose

As depicted in the film, Kerr struggled with addiction and took painkillers that were prescribed to him by a doctor. He began using opioids regularly to be able to continue fighting and numb the blows in the ring.
In a 2024 interview on the HJR Podcast, Kerr explained when he believes his addiction started.

“The two components that came together are the expectation that I’m supposed to perform at this level regardless,” he said. “And then the training to perform at that level. And when those two came together, it just created a storm where I’m like, I don’t have time.”
He called taking opiates a “shortcut” that helped “mask the pain.”
“It’s gonna allow me to get in the gym, allow me to train, allow me to maintain this expectation that I have of myself and. the Japanese have of me to compete at this level,” Kerr said.
“The Smashing Machine” showed the consequences of his drug use when Dawn found him unresponsive inside their Arizona home after an overdose.
In real life, Kerr overdosed twice, including in 1999. His recovery was also shown in the film after he checked himself into rehab.
In an October 2025 interview with The Ariel Helwani Show, Kerr confirmed that he's been sober for seven years.
A Tumultuous Relationship
Kerr and girlfriend-turned-wife Dawn's relationship also included many highs and lows.
From the start of the film, the couple, who lived in Arizona at the time, often had strained conversations before they eventually fought and got into heated, and at times, destructive arguments.
Whether it's Dawn making the wrong smoothie, Mark not inviting her to go to Japan for his tournaments or both dealing with his addiction recovery, the two pushed each other's buttons.

The film also depicted a the real-life moment when Dawn attempted to kill herself with a gun after Mark told her to leave their home. Kerr confirmed the moment in his HBO documentary, as well as in an interview with Time.com, sharing that Staples also attempted to hurt herself with razors before grabbing the handgun.

“What I was doing at the time was incredibly selfish. Dawn just wanted my love. She wanted to feel important. The only thing important at the time was me fighting, then the second thing that came in importance was the drug and alcohol use,” Kerr said about his and Staples fights. “A lot of that volatility was because of my actions. I look back on it now, she’s a little girl asking to be loved, and I’m just a little boy that doesn’t know how to accept or give it.”
The two would go on to get married, have a son, Bryce, together, before divorcing in 2006.
While on the “Joe Rogan Experience,” Kerr expressed that watching the film was therapeutic for him.

“It was therapy for me... For the first time, I could actually see my part in it,” he said. “Like I could see my part, how f------ hard I was on the people around me, how just singularly driven I was to accomplish something at all cost. And the person that paid it the most was Dawn. She paid a heavy price.”
In another interview with IndieWire, Kerr reflected on his and his ex-wife's relationship.

“It allowed me to see how hard I was on Dawn, and really admit that to myself,” Kerr said. “Fighting is incredibly selfish; it doesn’t leave a lot of space for other people when it comes to emotion and intimacy. Breaking it down to its essence, Dawn was just a little girl who wanted to be loved, and I was just a boy that couldn’t figure out how to love her.”
He expressed that both of them are different people now and their priority in life is their “beautiful 20-year-old son” and “to be the best parents we can to him.”
“When the movie showed at Venice, I couldn’t believe how emotionally impactful it was,” he added. “It was like therapy with a thousand people in the room. It was a beautiful experience.”
Kerr is now married to fitness consultant Franci Alberding and the two started a wellness company called Absolute Wellness.

title: Bad Bunny Fanboys Over 'KPop Demon Hunters' in 'SNL' Sketch Featuring Singing Group
summary: The “Kpop Demon Hunters” phenomenon has officially reached “Saturday Night Live.”Season 51 of the late-night sketch comedy show kicked off Oct.
story: The “Kpop Demon Hunters” phenomenon has officially reached “Saturday Night Live.”
Season 51 of the late-night sketch comedy show kicked off Oct. 4, 2025, with two-time host Bad Bunny and musical guest, Doja Cat.
The episode featured a sketch dedicated to “Kpop Demon Hunters,” which became the Netflix's most-watched animated film and the most popular film, per Tudum.

In the sketch, Sarah Sherman, Chloe Fineman, Bad Bunny and Mikey Day got together for a long overdue reunion. The friend group immediately started to talk about movies that they planned to see, including “One Battle After Another” and “Frankenstein.”
However, Bad Bunny’s interests went in a slightly different direction as he proudly declared, “Yeah, I like ‘Kpop Demon Hunters.’”
“Have you been watching it a bunch with your kids?” Sherman asked, to which Bad Bunny replied, “I don’t have kids.”
Day made a comment about how all of the kids he knows planned to dress up as the characters for Halloween, leaving Bad Bunny to interject, “It’s actually not for kids. It’s for smart adults.”

Fineman tried to change the subject and brought up her experience seeing Lady Gaga over the summer. However, Bad Bunny had tunnel vision on the Netflix hit as he interjected, “You know what music I like? ‘Kpop Demon Hunters.’”
Day made another attempt to move on from the topic, politely telling Bad Bunny that his new obsession was “cool,” but the rapper had a rebuttal of his own.
“Actually, it’s not ‘cool,’ dog,” he said. “In ‘Kpop Demon Hunters,’ songs are not just songs, they are weapons...What else is going to save you from demons, you idiot.”

Bad Bunny continued his impassioned speech about the movie, which caused even more tension at the table. Fineman attempted to diffuse the situation, but the rapper refused to participate in the conversation, turning away from the group with his arms folded across his chest.
While his friends talked about what had transpired over the last few years, Bad Bunny’s internal monologue took center stage.

“Those dumb idiots have no idea. Stupid dummies. I don’t care if they believe me, I have HUNTR/X on my side,” he said in a voiceover, before singers Ejae, Audrey Nuna and Rei Ami — who sang the vocals for the group in “Kpop Demon Hunters” — appeared in a thought bubble and began to sing.
Bad Bunny got called out by the group for ignoring Sherman’s story, though as he pointed out, her misfortune “sounds like the work of a demon.”
“If only there were three gorgeous Korean girls who could protect you, idiot,” he added.
While Fineman went to share more about her life, Bad Bunny returned to his internal monologue, even angrier than before.

When he was snapped back to reality, Fineman confessed to her recent blunder. Bad Bunny seemed shocked by the news initially, but in actuality, he was reacting to Bowen Yang entering as the demon Jinu from the movie.

Equipped with a microphone and his greatest weapon, “a voice,” Yang possessed Sherman and the group devolved into pure panic. Day immediately apologized to Bad Bunny for doubting him while Fineman asked for help.
However, they were no match for Jinu. At least, not by themselves.
“I cannot help you idiots!” Bad Bunny yelled. “But they can.”
Ejae, Audrey Nuna, and Rei Ami then came onto the stage to perform “Golden” live as the group began to dance, indoctrinated by the phenomenon themselves.
Since the movie’s premiere on June 20, “Kpop Demon Hunters” has blown up across mainstream media, with six songs from its soundtrack hitting Billboard’s Top 100 chart.

The movie has taken the world by storm and even grew a fanbase of dads at home who weren’t able to escape the catchy tunes — including TODAY’s own Craig Melvin who watched with his family over the summer.
Novak Djokovic even showed off his “Kpop Demon Hunters” dance moves after a win at the U.S. Open, which served as a birthday present for his daughter, Tara.
“Kpop Demon Hunters” also caught the attention from one of the biggest K-pop groups in the world, BTS, who sang songs from the move during their livestreams.

title: Cillian Murphy Explains His Disinterested Expression — and Why It Serves Him as an Actor
summary: Cillian Murphy weighed in on why he thinks it's important for actors to be known for their work and not necessarily their personality
story: Cillian Murphy weighed in on why he thinks it's important for actors to be known for their work and not necessarily their personality.
In a preview clip for the Oct. 5 "Sunday Sitdown With Willie Geist," the Academy Award-winning actor spoke with Sunday TODAY anchor about why he doesn't seem too interested in becoming a celebrity.

"One of the things I admire about you, Cillian, is your complete disinterest in being a celebrity or a movie star," Willie said while laughing. "And that you’re an actor and you wanna be known for your work, and you’ve pulled that off."
Willie then asked Murphy why it was important for people not to know too much about him personally.

"I’ve always felt that if you wanna try and inhabit somebody convincingly that it seems sensible that there wouldn’t be too much — that people wouldn’t have an impression of you as an individual that would in some way inhibit your ability to do that," Murphy said.

"That’s kind of what I’ve always felt," he continued. "I like the transformative nature of acting. So if you can kinda keep that as background, then I think it allows you more freedom as a performer, you know?"

Murphy made a name for himself in roles like Christopher Nolan's  "Batman Begins" and "Inception," and the popular series "Peaky Blinders." When he landed the role of J. Robert Oppenheimer in Nolan's epic film, "Oppenheimer," he not took home an Oscar, but also became more of a household name.
The three-hour film won seven Oscars, including the Academy Award for best picture and Murphy's Oscar for best actor in a leading role.

Since the release of "Oppenheimer," Murphy has gone on to star in the Zombie movie, "28 Days Later," and "Small Things Like These," a film adaptation of Irish author Claire Keegan's book of the same name.

That film follows an Irish father in the 1980s as he discovers abuse occurring at a local convent's Magdalene Laundry. At laundries across the country, "fallen women" were forced into unpaid labor until the last laundry closed in 1996, according to the BBC.
Murphy described learning of the scandal as a "collective trauma for people of a certain age" at a 2024 press conference, according to the Guardian.

“I think the irony of the book is that it’s a Christian man trying to act Christian in a dysfunctional Christian society. And it asks a lot of questions about publicity and silence and shame, all of those things,” Murphy said. “But I really don’t think the duty of art is to answer those questions, it’s to talk to them. And maybe it’s easier to absorb than an academic report, or a political report.”
Murphy's newest role is in Netflix's "Steve," in which he portrays the titular role of a headteacher at a school for boys with societal and behavioral issues. "Steve" is set to premiere on Oct. 3.

title: Bad Bunny Addresses Super Bowl Halftime Show During 'SNL' Opener With Ultimate Fan Jon Hamm
summary: Bad Bunny returned to “Saturday Night Live” for his second hosting gig to kick off Season 51 of the late-night sketch comedy show.
story: Bad Bunny returned to “Saturday Night Live” for his second hosting gig to kick off Season 51 of the late-night sketch comedy show.
The Puerto Rican rapper hosted the Oct. 4 season premiere, alongside musical guest, Doja Cat.

During his monologue, Bad Bunny referenced several recent moments in his career, including his historic residency in Puerto Rico over the summer and his upcoming stint as the 2026 Super Bowl halftime performer in February 2026.

Bad Bunny addressed the criticism the latter received in his monologue, poking fun at some of the concern expressed over his forthcoming performance, which, based on his concerts and recent residency, will predominantly be in Spanish, the country’s second-most spoken language.
“You might not know this, but I’m doing the Super Bowl halftime show,” Bad Bunny said. “I’m very happy and I think everyone is happy about it. Even Fox News.”
The monologue cut to an edited version of pundits from the network spliced together to state, “Bad Bunny is my favorite musician, and he should be the next president.”
“I mean wow, thank you,” Bad Bunny said. “But really, I’m very excited to be doing the Super Bowl. I know that people all around the world who love my music are also happy.”
Bad Bunny then began to speak entirely in Spanish, sharing a message for the Latino community and the achievement of his Super Bowl halftime performance.
He also had a cheeky message for the viewers who didn’t catch a word he said, adding, “And if you didn’t understand what I just said, you have four months to learn.”

At the beginning of his monologue, Bad Bunny touched on his residency in Puerto Rico, which ran from July 11 through Sept. 20. The rapper poked fun at some of his dance moves on stage, which he joked was actually very “complicated choreography.”
“My residency was beautiful. Everyone loved it,” he continued. “Some celebrities came to my show. A few of them were on drugs. I don’t want to say who, but this was Jon Hamm.”

The monologue cut to a video of the “Mad Men” actor on stage at Bad Bunny’s residency. Hamm, who donned a patterned shirt with matching shorts and a white bucket hat, vibed to Bad Bunny’s music as he bopped back and forth, flicking his wrist as he danced along.
“Actually, that wasn’t Jon Hamm, that was Juan Jamón,” Bad Bunny joked.

The camera then cut to the actor in the audience wearing the same outfit from the concert. Hamm appeared delighted to just be in the room, grinning wide as he pointed at the camera while he danced in his seat to applause from the crowd.
“I think he’s a little obsessed with me,” Bad Bunny quipped.

Hamm, a loud and proud fan of the rapper, attended Bad Bunny’s concert in Puerto Rico August. 16. There was no shortage of fun for Hamm, who appeared on stage at one point during the show, dancing with no inhibitions to the music.

During his Aug. 31 episode of “Sunday Sitdown” with Willie Geist, Bad Bunny reacted to Hamm’s dancing during his performance. At the time he said, “I saw him there on the casita probably, he was lit. I’m happy that he went and he had fun.”

title: Eric Dane Reveals He Missed the Emmys Due to Being Hospitalized
summary: Eric Dane reveals why he missed the 2025 Emmys when he was supposed to present an award alongside his "Grey's Anatomy" co-star Jesse Williams.
story: Eric Dane is sharing why he was noticeably absent from the 2025 Emmys.
The "Grey's Anatomy" star was expected to  present an award alongside his co-star Jesse Williams at the Sept. 14 ceremony but ultimately didn't appear on stage.
In an interview with The Washington Post that was published on Oct. 2, Dane revealed that he missed the awards show due to being hospitalized after experiencing a fall.
Dane, who announced his ALS diagnosis in April, said that shortly before the broadcast, he lost his balance and fell in the kitchen, causing him to get stitches.
“ALS is a nasty disease. … So I was in the hospital during the Emmys getting stitches put in my head,” he said.

“I missed an opportunity I was really looking forward to. It would have been great to see Jesse and get reunited with some of my peers, and to be able to present in front of my colleagues I thought would have a been special moment," he added. "So I was a really upset about it, but you know, there was nothing I could do about it.”
Dane took to Instagram on Sept. 15, one day after the Emmys, to say he's working with “I Am ALS“ on its Push for Progress initiative to find a cure for the disease.

“I’m Eric Dane. An actor, a father and now a person living with ALS,” he said in the video. “For over a century, ALS has been incurable, and we’re done accepting the status quo. We need the fastest path to a cure.”
In April, the "Euphoria" actor, who shares two kids with wife, Rebecca Gayheart, revealed he was diagnosed with ALS in an interview with People.
“I kindly ask that you give my family and I privacy during this time," he told the publication.
ALS is short for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and it's a "progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord," according to the ALS Association.

"The motor nerves affected when you have ALS are the motor neurons that provide voluntary movements and muscle control," per the ALS Association. As a result, the association explains that people may lose muscle control and the ability to “speak, eat, move and breathe” as the motor neurons degenerate.
Despite his ALS diagnosis, Dane said he still plans on acting for as long as he's able.
“I’m going to ride this till the wheels fall off,” he told E! News in June. “Keeps me sharp. It keeps me moving forward, which is super important right now.”

title: Kim Kardashian Channels Kris Jenner With Edgy Pixie Cut at Paris Fashion Week
summary: Kim Kardashian attended Paris Fashion Week with Kylie Jenner and showed off her new pixie cut hairstyle that fans say make her look like mom Kris Jenner.
story: Kris Jenner isn't the only member of her family who can rock a pixie cut.
In a Oct. 4 Instagram post, Kim Kardashian shared some photos of herself rocking a hairstyle that's reminiscent of the short hairdo  her mom, Kris Jenner, is known for.
"PARIS PIXIE," Kardashian captioned the snaps.
The first pic shows Kardashian looking at the camera head on, while the second pic shows her side profile.
In the comments, fans compared her to the family matriarch.
“Ok, calm down Kris Jenner,” one person wrote.
Another said, “Stunning 🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥.”
A third added, “Totally thought this was Kris when I was scrolling through the feed. Love this 😍.”
The "Kardashians" star wore the look while attending Maison Margiela fashion show on Oct. 4 during Paris Fashion Week. Her sister, Kylie Jenner, was also in attendance.
For the event, Kardashian rocked a long grey trench coat and a pair of black boots with clear heels. Jenner, on the other hand, donned an all-white outfit with a pair of matching heels.
That same day, Kardashian was also seen wearing her pixie cut outside the Alaïa show, wearing a structured black corset top with a sheer skirt and black jacket.

Kardashian has changed up her hair a number of times in the past. In 2022, she debuted a beach blond look and also dyed her eyebrows the same color for a photo shoot in the September issue of Interview Magazine.
A few years prior, in 2020, she dyed her hair red and showed off her new look on social media.
“You guys, I dyed my hair red. Do you love it?” she said in a clip posted on X.
Kardashian isn't the only family member who has changed up her look from time to time. In 2024, Kylie Jenner got a pixie cut and Kourtney Kardashian recently trimmed her hair and got bangs.

title: Hilary Duff Shows Off Dance Moves in Surprise Appearance as Role Model's Sally
summary: Role Model invited Hilary Duff on stage to dance with him when he played his hit song “Sally, When the Wine Runs Out" on stage in Texas.
story: Hilary Duff is the latest celebrity to play "Sally" at Role Model's concert.

On her Instagram stories, Duff, 38, posted a video of her dancing on stage with Role Model when he was performing his hit song “Sally, When the Wine Runs Out" at the Austin City Limits Music Festival in Texas.
At one part in the performance, Duff gave Role Model a big hug before she was seen exiting the stage.

For the event, Duff wore a cropped black shirt and a mini skirt. On her Instagram stories, she also posted a photo of herself holding up an envelope that said "Sally" while she rode in a cart outside.
During her performance, also captured by fans, Role Model gave a special nod to Duff’s 2003 song, “What Dreams Are Made Of,” which was featured in the actor's The Lizzie McGuire Movie.
“This is what dreams are made of, baby” the 28-year-old singer yelled into the microphone as he and Duff danced together.
Since the 2024 release of his song, Role Model has made it a tradition to bring celebrities on stage with him when he sings “Sally, When the Wine Runs Out.”
Some other stars who have taken on the role of Sally are Natalie Portman, Kate Hudson, and TODAY's Al Roker.
The song tells the story of a "wild" girl named Sally who steals Role Model's heart. Throughout the song, he raves about her personality and secretly hopes she's not seeing anyone else.
In the chorus, he says, "Sally / That feeling’s coming around / Please don’t go falling in love / Then disappear when the wine runs out."

Duff's appearance on stage comes nearly two months after she teased her return to music. In September, she posted some photos of herself in a recording studio and captioned it, "new music … or something 🪩✨🍒."

That same month, Atlantic Records released a press release that said she signed a deal with them and will also be coming out with an “intimate docuseries” that will chronicle her return to music. Duff hasn't released an album since 2015’s “Breathe In. Breathe Out."

The docuseries will embrace “the ups, downs, and everything in between” and show Duff “as she balances raising a family, recording new music, live show rehearsals, and preparing to perform on stage for the first time in over a decade," the press release read.

title: 'Golden Bachelor' Gerry Turner Announces He's Getting Married 1 Year After Theresa Nist Divorce
summary: "Golden Bachelor" star Gerry Turner got engaged to his girlfriend, Lana Sutton. See pictures of her new engagement ring!
story: "Golden Bachelor" star Gerry Turner is ready to walk down the aisle again.
On Instagram, Turner announced that he and his girlfriend, Lana Sutton, are officially engaged. To share the news, he posted some photos of them together with her donning her new engagement ring.
In two of the photos, Turner is seen standing next to his fiancée on the beach while she places her hand on his chest to show off her new bling.
He captioned the snaps, "We’ve got BIG news. The Golden Bachelor is OFF the market. I found my perfect match and she said 'YES'. I Love this woman."
Turner's engagement comes 15 months after he filed for divorce from "Golden Bachelor" winner Theresa Nist in April 2024.

“Theresa and I have had a number of heart-to-heart conversations, and we’ve looked closely at our situation, our living situation, so forth and — and we’ve kind of come to the conclusion mutually that it’s probably time for us to — dissolve our marriage,” he said in an interview that aired on ABC in April 2024.

Though their relationship didn't work out, Turner has since found love again. In an April interview on the “Bachelor Happy Hour” podcast, the reality TV star, who revealed he’s been diagnosed with an incurable form of bone marrow cancer in December, said he was dating someone new.

“I am dating someone,” he teased of his new relationship with Sutton. “I think at this point it’s going well. But I don’t want to say too much and jinx it and I’m trying to respectfully get to a point where there’s an acceptable amount of time from my divorce.”

Turner explained that Nist knows he's been seeing someone and he's been doing his best to "slow roll" his relationship. He also said his kids, Jenny Young and Angie Warner, have already met his new girlfriend.

“I think the fun part there is she has daughters that I really relate to, and she relates well to my daughters,” he said. “So we’ve been around each other briefly. It’s been fun. It’s been a very enjoyable encounter.”

Since the reveal, Turner has posted many pictures of him and Sutton together on Instagram. In one post, there're seen vacationing in the UK, and in another they're seen going to Paris and London together.

"The past two months have been an absolute blast — travel, adventure, and quality time with two families. Feeling grateful to have met such a kind-hearted woman. What a partner!" Turner shared on Instagram in May.

title: What Chase Infiniti Said to Leonardo DiCaprio to Get Him to Do TikToks for 'One Battle After Another'
summary: “One Battle After Another” star Chase Infiniti explains how she was able to get her on screen co-stars, like Leonardo DiCaprio, to participate in TikTok trends.
story: “One Battle After Another” star Chase Infiniti admits it took a bit of arm twisting to get some of the cast, including her on-screen co-star Leonardo DiCaprio, to jump on the TikTok trend bandwagon to promote their latest film.

In the Paul Thomas Anderson action thriller, Infiniti plays Willa, the daughter of Bob (DiCaprio), a fatigued former revolutionary and over protective father. After Willa is kidnapped by her father’s former enemy, Col. Steven J. Lockjaw (Sean Penn) — who was also behind the disappearance of her mother, Perfidia Beverly Hills (Teyana Taylor) — she and Bob fight for their survival.

Leading up to the Sept. 26 release of the film, Infiniti enlisted her co-stars Regina Hall, Teyana Taylor, Benicio del Toro, Leo DiCaprio and Sean Penn for a series of social media promos that nodded to current internet trends.

She even tapped the film’s director Anderson for the “Oh, That’s Not Bad” trend, and managed to snag DiCaprio for a remix to the “Bob Girl Summer” trend, with the Oscar winner lipsyncing Nicki Minaj’s verse on the “B.o.B” song.

The film’s social media promos, which quickly went viral and amassed millions of views across platforms, were an immediate hit online with early support from the director, DiCaprio and the Warner Bros. marketing team, who helped to spearhead the campaign.

Speaking to TODAY.com about how it all came together, Infiniti explains that after being given the directive to “start making TikToks,” she says it took a bit of persuading to actually get her co-stars on board.

“I remember right when we were about to start the press tour, Paul and Leo were like, ‘Hey, we need you to get on Tiktok and you start making TikToks.’ And I was like, ‘OK, you guys are going to have to be in them too. I hope you’re ready for that,” she says. “And then I would literally just show up with different, like, trends or ideas that I would see and I would show an example.”
She continues, “I’d be like, ‘Do you like this? Yes or no?’ And then if they said ‘Yes,’ or if I could convince them, then we would get the Tiktok.”
So what did Infiniti actually say to “convince” her seemingly reluctant co-stars like DiCaprio, del Toro, Penn and even director Anderson to participate in these Gen Z-influenced trends?
Infiniti reveals a little begging and one magic word did the trick.

“I feel like all the convincing was … kind of like, ‘Please, can we please, do it? I promise it’s cool. I promise it’s fun,’” she says, before later sharing her personal plea to Sean Penn. “I was like, ‘Please, please be in the video, Sean, it would be so good.’”
The “One Battle After Another” breakout star says it did take some heavy maneuvering and hand-holding for her to get the TikTok trends just right.

“It was me being like, ‘Stand here. You’re going to say this,’ or, ‘You don’t have to say anything, but you’re going to stand here and move here.’ And it was kind of me just placing them where they needed to go,” she says.
Eventually, Infiniti explains, “the more that we did it, the more that they enjoyed them."
The real test of success was when she was given a thumbs up of approval by Anderson’s kids, whom he shares with actor Maya Rudolph.
“So I was like, ‘That’s how I know that I’m doing it right,’” she quipped.

Now, following the film’s release, the breakout star can easily break a smile as she reflects on her uncanny ability to turn Baby Boomers into certified TikTok stars. But, Infiniti shares, there is one specific promo that’s her pièce de résistance and lives in her head rent free.
“The one I was the most excited to get was the, ‘What’s your name? B.o.B. So they calling you Bob,’ with Leo. I was very happy to get that one,” she beams.

While the film’s promotional run has come to an end, “One Battle After Another” seems to keep the door open for more of the story. When asked if there could be a sequel following the dark comedy’s dramatic ending, Infiniti tells TODAY.com that she’s open to it and teases what she’d like to see.

“I think that if Willa and Perfidia ever had the chance to reunite, getting to witness that and to see how that would play out would be really interesting, because of the time spent apart, the things that have happened in between,” she says.
“I think that that feels like a wonderful close of the book, closing the chapter temporarily. I’m not sure what will happen in the future, but that’s why we’re hopeful,” she says.
As far as where the story may go for her character’s dad Bob, Infiniti jokes she hopes he finally gets the help he needs.

“I hope Bob does not stay as paranoid,” she says. “I think that my biggest hope for Bob is that he can actually, like, sit on the couch and chill. He doesn’t have to be as paranoid as he has been in the past.”
“One Battle After Another” is now in theaters nationwide.

title: Is ‘Saturday Night Live’ New Tonight, Oct. 4?
summary: “Saturday Night Live” is back! Season 51 kicks off with a premiere hosted by Bad Bunny.
story: “Saturday Night Live” is back!
Following an over four-month summer hiatus, the historic live comedy show is returning for Season 51, bringing a cast of beloved players and fresh faces to 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

After the previous season of “SNL” celebrated 50 years of laughs, creator Lorne Michaels vowed to “shake things up” around Studio 8H. Over the past several weeks, former cast members Ego Nwodim, Heidi Gardner, Michael Longfellow, Devon Walker and Emil Wakim revealed they will not be returning to the show. Meanwhile, new comics on the scene this season include Tommy Brennan, Jeremy Culhane, Kam Patterson and Veronika Slowikowska.
Is There a New Episode of ‘SNL’ on Tonight?
Yes, “SNL” Season 51 kicks off Saturday, Oct. 4, with host Bad Bunny and musical guest Doja Cat.

While Bad Bunny was the musical guest for the final episode of Season 50 in May, Saturday's show marks the “Debí Tirar Más Fotos” rapper's second time serving as host. His hosting debut in October 2023 during Season 49 led to several viral clips and characters.
A week before his sophomore hosting gig, Bad Bunny was announced as the headliner for the 2026 Super Bowl halftime show.
How to Watch ‘SNL’

The first episode of “SNL” Season 51 will air live on NBC at 11:30 p.m. ET. The show will also be available to stream the next day on Peacock. (Peacock and TODAY.com share a parent company, NBCUniversal.)
Who Is Hosting ‘SNL’ This Season?
Earlier this month, “SNL” revealed the show’s hosts and musical guests for the first three weeks of October.
Saturday, Oct. 4: host Bad Bunny with musical guest Doja Cat Saturday, Oct. 11: host Amy Poehler with musical guest Role Model Saturday, Oct. 18: host and music guest Sabrina Carpenter
Saturday, Oct. 4: host Bad Bunny with musical guest Doja Cat
Saturday, Oct. 11: host Amy Poehler with musical guest Role Model
Saturday, Oct. 18: host and music guest Sabrina Carpenter

title: Selena Gomez Reveals She Left Her Wedding 'A Little Earlier Than Most' in BTS Pics
summary: Selena Gomez continues to share behind-the-scenes looks from her and Benny Blanco's wedding day
story: Selena Gomez continues to share behind-the-scenes looks from her and Benny Blanco's wedding day.
The "Only Murders in the Building" star and her music producer husband got married on Sept. 27, 2025. She confirmed the news on her Instagram, sharing photos and video from her special day.
On Oct. 3, Gomez posted a handful of photos that appear to be taken before she walked down the aisle up until she left her reception earlier than expected.
“From writing my vows to leaving my wedding a little earlier than most..,” Gomez captioned the Instagram slideshow.

Photos included in her post show Gomez in a navy blue robe with roses, wearing sparkly cat-eye sunglasses with a veil. She's also seen in silky pink pajamas seemingly writing her vows. There's also a photo of her and Blanco arm-in-arm and walking on the beach, as well as white chocolate covered strawberries decorated as a bride and groom, among other pics.
The final snap in the bunch shows Gomez in a white dress and flats, seemingly leaving her reception early.
The couple, who announced their engagement in December 2024, have been sharing snippets from their nuptials in recent days.
Shortly after they said “I do,” Blanco posted his own photos of the two, captioning the Instagram post, “I married a real life disney princess.”
Gomez commented, “I love you soooo much,” with a white heart.

The “Same Old Love” singer wore three wedding dresses for her wedding festivities, all designed by Ralph Lauren. According to the designer, her satin gown with the halter neckline, embroidery and 3D florals was “for the wedding.”
Her second gown was made out of “300 hand-shaped and applied lace flowers” and included the couple's initials and wedding date sewn into the design.
Her third, seen above in her most recent BTS slideshow, was a shorter look with a voluminous underskirt.
The newlyweds haven't been shy about sharing photos from their wedding day. Among their pics include a look at their new bands.
To accompany Gomez's marquise diamond engagement ring, she paired it with a larger diamond wedding band. Blanco, on his end, opted for a gold ring.

Additionally, Gomez has also shared a breakdown and look at her wedding day makeup. She even created a “wedding kit” bundle that included the products she used from her Rare Beauty company to share with her fans.

title: 'Gilmore Girls' Stars Reunite to Celebrate Lauren Graham at Her Walk of Fame Ceremony
summary: Lauren Graham’s former “Gilmore Girls” co-stars showed up to cheer her on at her Hollywood Walk of Fame ceremony in Los Angeles on Oct.
story: Lauren Graham’s former “Gilmore Girls” co-stars showed up to cheer her on at her Hollywood Walk of Fame ceremony in Los Angeles on Oct. 3.

In a scene right out of Stars Hollow, Graham reunited with castmates Scott Patterson, Kelly Bishop, Matt Czuchry and Yanic Truesdale. Sam Pancake, who appeared in the hit show's 2016 revival “Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life,” acted as the star-studded ceremony's emcee.
Graham, who played witty single mom Lorelai Gilmore on the show, said she was “proud” of the work she’d done and felt “lucky to have gotten to work with some incredible writers and showrunners.”

While at the podium, Graham jokingly noted that only one of the three actors who portrayed the hotly-debated love interests of her TV daughter Rory, played by Alexis Bledel, had shown up to the ceremony.
“Czuchry is here. (Milo) Ventimiglia, no. (Jared) Padalecki,” she observed before quipping, “Points for Logan. Um, just points. Just points. It’s an ongoing system... It isn’t done yet.”
She also thanked “Gilmore Girls” fans for being so “kind” and “enthusiastic.”

“I’m so moved when you come up to me in — usually at the airport bathroom,” she said to laughter, “and tell me how much the show has meant to you and that you’ve shared it with a family member and maybe passed it on to another generation.”
Graham also saluted “Gilmore Girls’ co-creator Amy Sherman-Palladino, saying, “Sometimes I feel we share a brain and kind of have a relationship where I hear what she intends when she writes.”
She called being able to say the dialogue in Sherman-Palladino’s scripts “an incredible gift.”
Sherman-Palladino also spoke at the ceremony, recalling that she worried the role of Lorelai was “uncastable” before she met Graham and knew immediately, “It’s her.”
She praised Graham’s talent as an actor, calling her “this wonderful woman who’s given me my career.”
Bledel did not attend the ceremony, though she and Graham reunited last month to present an award at the 2025 Emmy Awards.

Patterson, who played Lorelai's friend and eventual love interest, coffee shop owner Luke Danes, shared a video from the ceremony on Instagram, writing, "Congratulations to Lauren Graham on your Hollywood Walk of Fame Star! I’m so proud of you!"

title: Would Robert Irwin Ever Be On 'The Bachelor'? What He Said
summary: Robert Irwin weighs in on the idea of looking for love on "The Bachelor."
story: Robert Irwin has gained a legion of devoted fans since making his debut on "Dancing With the Stars" last month, and some of them are rallying for him to be the next star of "The Bachelor."
